newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Singapore shares end higher, blue chips firmer.
newsitem.headline: Singapore shares end higher, blue chips firmer.

text.p: Singapore's key share index closed higher on Tuesday as blue chips ended firmer at the last minute, although dealers said they saw no reason for the rise.
They said the market was directionless, with an early run-up in Malaysian over-the-counter shares overtaken by a last minute rise in blue chips.
"There were few buyers, but they definitely had guts," said an institutional dealer of the surge in blue chips.
The key Straits Times Industrials Index was 13.23 points up at 2,111.68, in line with Wall Street's two consecutive gains.
Market volume was a moderate 90.81 million shares with advances ahead of declines by 175 to 128.

Malaysia's Samanda Holdings topped the gainers on various rumours. "But it could be a rotational play since the stocks were tightly controlled and easy to manipulate for syndicate players," said a dealer with a local brokerage.
It surged Singapore $1.05 to S$9.20 on 95,000 shares traded.
Singapore Press foreign rose S$0.50 to $23.90 and Cycle & Carriage was up S$0.30 to S$13.50.
Roly International was the most active with 8.61 million shares trade, but the price was unchanged at S$0.675.
